III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement
Section (4) An agency shall consider all the following factors in selecting
Description an appropriate placement for a child:
(a) proximity to the child’s parents, family, or community.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency did not consider proximity to child's parents and family
when making placement decisions.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant – During the course of an investigation involving a
different agency it was discovered that some of the allegations
being investigated would have occurred prior to that agency
accepting case responsibility. The alleged violations would have
taken place while Kalamazoo DHHS carried case responsibility.
An internal complaint was filed to open a new investigation.
Parent A – Parent A filed the initial complaint on 9/25/2023
naming a different agency. Phone interviews were scheduled with
Parent A, through email exchanges. Calls were made at the
agreed upon time, but she did not answer on 10/6/2023 or
10/10/2023. Parent A did return the missed call on 10/10/2023
and left a voicemail stating she was available the remainder of the
day. A return call was made within 30 minutes, but she did not
answer. On 10/11/2023 Parent A sent an email requesting
interview availability for that day which was provided to her along
with a request for her to call when she was available. She has not
responded.
The only available information from the complainant is what she
wrote in her online compliant which stated the following:
The Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C were not placed with
consideration of their parents and communities’ proximity to
the home as they were placed in Galesburg (21 miles
away) and Centerville (35 miles away).
Chief Administrator - On 11/9/2023 an email was sent to Chief
Administrator informing him of the allegations and requesting the
names of the staff who were assigned at the time the alleged
violations would have occurred. He replied on 11/13/2023 stating
Foster Care Worker and Supervisor were assigned the case;
however, Foster Care Worker no longer works for the agency and
Supervisor now works for a different division of the department.
He added that neither he, nor the current program managers were
2

in their current roles at the time of the alleged violations, so they
would not have any knowledge of what occurred.
Foster Care Worker - On 11/9/2023 a search of the state
employee directory was conducted. It was verified that Foster
Care Worker no longer works for the department.
Supervisor- On 11/27/2023 Supervisor was interviewed by
phone. She reported she did not recall much about the case but
reviewed the case record which documented the youths were
already placed in their respective foster homes at the time she
was assigned.
DHHS Specialist – On 11/20/2023 a search of the state
employee directory was conducted, and it was determined DHHS
Specialist no longer works for the department.
Licensing Supervisor – The Licensing Supervisor who worked
for the agency at the time the youths involved in this complaint
came into care no longer works for the agency; however, she still
works for the department, so she was contacted via email. She
responded she remembers the family involved in this investigation
and participated in several meeting at the onset of this case and
provided the following timeline of events regarding removal and
initial placement of the youths:
• 10/4/2021, a licensed home was identified for placement of
all three youths. A plan was made to place all three in that
home as the priority was to keep the siblings together.
• 10/4/2021-10/5/2021, all three youths were AWOL.
• 10/5/2021, the youths were located at school and
transported to the identified foster home. When they
arrived, the foster parents indicated they thought Youth B
was a younger child and they didn’t realize his diabetic care
was so extensive.
• Licensing Supervisor was contacted by DHHS Specialist
regarding a new search for placement of Youth B.
• Licensing Supervisor’s team conducted an extensive
placement search and located a family able to provide for
Youth B’s medical needs, so he was placed in that home,
which was 12 miles from Parent A’s address, not 21 as
stated in the complaint allegation.
• Youth A & Youth C remained in the home they were
originally placed since the home that could provide for
Youth B’s needs could not take all three siblings and the
3

agency made the decision to at least keep the two siblings
together.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
The following is documented in the electronic case record:
• 10/4/2021 phone conversation with paternal grandmother
who expressed interest in placement; however, reported a
history of DHHS involvement. She reported there were no
other relatives willing to take placement of the youths.
• 10/4/2023, attempted phone call to maternal grandmother
by DHHS Specialist.
• 10/4/2021 -10/5/2021, Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C were
AWOL.
• 10/5/2021, Parent A and Parent B were notified by phone
the youths would be placed in licensed foster homes. No
response was received.
• 10/5/2021, Youth A, and Youth C were picked up from
school by DHHS Specialist and placed in their respective
foster homes where they have remained placed.
• 10/7/2021 Relative Notification Letter sent to the paternal
grandmother.
• 10/8/2021 Action Summary completed by DHHS Specialist
documenting the parents were contacted on 10/5/2021 and
informed the youths would be placed in licensed foster
homes.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as initial priority for placement
was given to keeping the youths together. A home was found
willing to take placement of all three children. When it was
determined that family could not provide for Youth B’s medical
needs, a home was located for him within 20 miles of his parents’
home.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement
Section (4) An agency shall consider all of the following factors in selecting
Description an appropriate placement for a child:
(b) the physical, emotional, and educational needs of the child
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency did not take into consideration the youths' educational
needs when making placement decisions.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant – An internal complaint was filed; therefore, there is
no Complainant to interview.
4

Parent A - Phone interviews were scheduled with Parent A;
however, she did not answer at any of the times scheduled.
The only information is what she wrote in her initial online
complaint which stated:
• The children were removed from their school and put in
new schools in the area they were placed.
Chief Administrator - On 11/9/2023 Chief Administrator reported
no one who was assigned to this case currently works for the
agency.
Foster Care Worker - On 11/9/2023 a search of the state
employee directory was conducted. It was verified that Foster
Care Worker no longer works for the department.
Supervisor- On 11/27/2023 Supervisor was interviewed by
phone. She reported she did not recall much about the case but
reviewed the case record which documented the youths were
already placed in their respective foster homes at the time she
was assigned.
DHHS Specialist – On 11/20/2023 a search of the state
employee directory was conducted, and it was determined DHHS
Specialist no longer works for the department.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
The following is documented in the electronic case record:
• 10/8/2021 Action Summary completed by DHHS Specialist
documenting it was unknown if youths will require the child
to change schools and that the education planner has been
referred to assist.
• Documentation that the youths remained in the school in
which they were enrolled at the time of removal until
10/13/2021.
• 10/13/2021 documentation of enrollment in new schools to
reduce travel time.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as the youth were placed with
priority to keep siblings together as well as to provide for Youth
B’s medical needs. The youth remained in their school of origin
initially; however, despite an education planner becoming
involved, school placement did change due to the distance being
travelled daily.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement
Section (4) An agency shall consider all of the following factors in selecting
Description an appropriate placement for a child.
(d) expressed preferences of the child, and the child’s parent or
parent.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency did not consider the preference of the parents when
making placement decisions.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant – An internal complaint was filed; therefore, there is
no Complainant to interview.
Parent A - Phone interviews were scheduled with Parent A;
however, she did not answer at any of the times scheduled.
The only information is what she wrote in her initial online
complaint which stated:
We were not notified of placement decision, nor did we
have any part of the decision.
Chief Administrator - On 11/9/2023 Chief Administrator reported
no one who was assigned to this case currently works for the
agency.
Foster Care Worker - On 11/9/2023 a search of the state
employee directory was conducted. It was verified that Foster
Care Worker no longer works for the department.
Supervisor- On 11/27/2023 Supervisor was interviewed by
phone. She reported she did not recall much about the case but
reviewed the case record which documented the youths were
already placed in their respective foster homes at the time she
was assigned.
DHHS Specialist – On 11/20/2023 a search of the state
employee directory was conducted, and it was determined DHHS
Specialist no longer works for the department.
Licensing Supervisor – Licensing Supervisor, who worked for
the agency at the time the youths involved in this complaint came
into care no longer works for the agency; however, she still works
for the department, so she was contacted via email. She
responded she remembers the family involved in this investigation
and participated in several meeting at the onset of this case and
6

provided the following timeline of events regarding removal and
initial placement of the youths:
• September of 2021, an initial Team Decision making
meeting was held to discuss the case. Parent A and Parent
B did not attend. Attempts to contact them during the
meeting were made but they did not answer the phone;
therefore, they were not able to provide their input
regarding placement decision.
• 10/12/2021, another TDM was held and again, neither
Parent A nor Parent B showed up; therefore, they were not
able to provide their input regarding placement decision.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
The following is documented in the electronic case record:
• 9/21/2021, DHHS Specialist left a voice mail message and
sent a text message to Parent A regarding a TDM
scheduled for 9/22/2021 including instructions how to
connect to the virtual meeting.
• 9/22/2021, DHHS Specialist left a voice mail message and
sent a text message to Parent A regarding the TDM
scheduled for that day including instructions how to connect
to the virtual meeting.
• 9/22/2021, TDM paperwork documenting neither Parent A
nor Parent B attended the meeting. Attempts to contact
both by phone during the meeting were unsuccessful.
• 9/30/2021, 10/1/2021 and 10/4/2021, Unsuccessful contact
attempts via phone calls, text messages, and emails with
Parent A and Parent B
• 10/4/2021, multiple contact attempts including a visit to
Parent A and Parent B’s home during which they refused to
come out of the house or speak to DHHS Specialist about
the upcoming removal hearing that day. Each contact
included DHHS Specialist providing Parent A and Parent B
the details, either verbally or in writing, of the court hearing
scheduled for the following day.
• 10/4/2021, phone calls to both Parent A & Parent B by
DHHS Specialist, neither answered.
• 10/4/2021 phone conversation with paternal grandmother
who expressed interest in placement; however, reported a
history of DHHS involvement. She reported there were no
other relatives willing to take placement of the youths.
• 10/4/2023, attempted phone call to maternal grandmother,
with whom Parent A and Parent B live, by DHHS Specialist.
• 10/4/2021, Youth A, Youth B, Youth C were court ordered
to be removed from their parents’ care. Neither Parent A,
nor Parent B appeared for the hearing.
7

• 10/4/2021, attempted face to face by DHHS Specialist with
Parent A and Parent B at their home to inform them of
hearing outcome. No one answered the door. A copy of the
removal order was left at the home.
• 10/4/2021 -10/5/2021, Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C were
AWOL.
• 10/5/201, DHHS Specialist sent a text message to Parent A
requesting a response.
• 10/5/2021 text from Parent A indicating she was meeting
with an attorney. DHHS Specialist responded asking if she
would like to talk while she was with her attorney. No
response was received.
• 10/5/2021 case contact documenting the youths were
picked up from school and transported to their respective
placements where they have remained placed.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as efforts were made to
engage the family in discussion prior to removal of the youths from
the parental home. The parents did not cooperate with meetings
or discussions regarding placement of the youths, despite being
offered the opportunity.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
Section (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the following
Description information before the placement or replacement of a child:
(C) Available known information about the child’s health.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation One of the youths reported going without his medication resulting
in hospital care due to the foster family not knowing how to
administer his medication.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant – An internal complaint was filed; therefore, there is
no Complainant to interview.
Parent A - Phone interviews were scheduled with Parent A;
however, she did not answer at any of the times scheduled.
The only information is what she wrote in her initial online
complaint which stated:
• Youth B did not receive his Insulin the night of removal.
• Youth B was hospitalized October 6, 2021, due to not
eating all day and no one knowing how to administer his
medication.
8

Chief Administrator - On 11/9/2023 Chief Administrator reported
no one who was assigned to this case currently works for the
agency.
Foster Care Worker - On 11/9/2023 a search of the state
employee directory was conducted. It was verified that Foster
Care Worker no longer works for the department.
Supervisor- On 11/27/2023 Supervisor was interviewed by
phone. She reported she did not recall much about the case but
remembered that Youth B was removed from his parents’ care in
part due to their failure to meet his medical needs. She stated she
recalls discussing Youth B’s medical needs during the meeting
that took place when she was assigned the case. Supervisor
reported Youth B was in his foster home less than 24 hour before
needing emergency treatment for high blood glucose level. She
stated she doesn’t recall if the medical providers indicated
specifics as to why his blood glucose levels were so high.
DHHS Specialist – On 11/20/2023 a search of the state
employee directory was conducted, and it was determined DHHS
Specialist no longer works for the department.
Licensing Supervisor – The Licensing Supervisor who worked
for the agency at the time the youths involved in this complaint
came into care no longer works for the agency; however, she still
works for the department, so she was contacted via email. She
responded she remembers the family involved in this investigation
and participated in several meeting at the onset of this case. She
reported Youth B did not have an established Primary Care
Provider when he came into care, and he had missed at least two
endocrinologist appointments prior to removal. The parents were
uncooperative with the removal process, so the children were
retrieved by DHHS Specialist from school the day after removal.
Youth B had been with his parents and at school prior to being
removed and being placed in the foster home.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
The following is documented in the electronic case record:
• 10/1/2021, face to face between DHHS Specialist and
Youth B’s Endocrinologist who reported Youth B’s school
contacted her office 9/1/2021 due to Youth B’s blood
glucose level running between 400-500 and requesting a
care plan.
• 10/1/2021, case contact between DHHS Specialist and
Youth B’s endocrinology nurse who reported Youth B is
9

scheduled for quarterly appointments and he was a no
show for appointments scheduled 3/29/21, 7/26/21 &
10/1/2021.
• 10/5/2021 email from endocrinologist to DHHS Specialist
with Youth B’s diabetic care regimen.
• 10/5/2021, at 3:10 PM DHHS Specialist picked Youth B up
from school to place him in foster care. The school staff
informed DHHS Specialist that the battery in Youth B’s
blood sugar monitoring device was almost depleted and a
charger for the device was not sent to school with him.
• 10/5/2021, DHHS Specialist met Parent A at a pharmacy to
obtain Youth B’s medical supplies before transporting
Youth B to his foster home where DHHS Specialist
provided the caregivers with the medical information and
explained the nighttime medication routine to the
caregivers.
• 10/5/2022, DHHS 3307 signed by Youth B’s foster parents
documenting they were informed of Youth B’s diabetes.
• 10/5/2021, DHHS Specialist emailed Youth B’s diabetic
care regimen previously provided by his endocrinologist to
his caregivers.
• 10/5/2021, case transfer meeting to foster care between
DHHS Specialist, Foster Care Worker, and Supervisor.
• 10/5/2021, discussion between DHHS Specialist and
Foster Care Worker documenting appointment with
endocrinologist would need to be scheduled.
• 10/6/2021, at 7:25 AM DHHS Specialist transported Youth
B to school. When he got out of the car, he vomited due to
a blood glucose level of 444 and high ketones. DHHS
Specialist transported Youth B to the emergency room.
• Placement documentation indicating Youth B stayed at the
hospital from 10/6/2021 until 10/9/2021 while hospital staff
worked to get his blood glucose level under control.
• Endocrinologist notes documenting the foster parent
brought Youth B to appointments in October, November,
and December of 2021.
• 10/22/2021 Initial Service Plan documenting one of the
reasons for the children’s placement in foster care was due
to medical neglect of Youth B resulting from
mismanagement of his diabetes resulting in hospitalization.
• 11/9/2021 DHHS Specialist report which states Youth B
was in the hospital for several hours on 8/29/2021 while
medical staff worked to get his blood glucose level of over
10

500 under control. The report indicated Youth B’s parents
were not checking his blood glucose levels before meals
and leaving the meter used to check his levels at home
when they were away.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as they obtained Youth B’s
medical information and supplies which were provided to his foster
parents at the time of placement. Additionally, Youth B was
previously hospitalized for high blood glucose levels and his
school reported high levels in the weeks prior to removal from his
parental home. Youth B’s removal was in part due to missing
specialist appointments and mismanagement of his blood glucose
levels. The hospitalization on 10/6/2023 occurred within 16 hours
of removal from his parents’ care, most of which were sleeping
hours.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
